Article Title: Behind spin-heavy Champions Trophy squad: Need to bat deep, tired pitches
Article Text:
Arshdeep Singh, Kuldeep Yadav and Varun Chakravarthy. (PTI Photo)

Poll What Do You Think About India’s Spin-Heavy Squad for the Champions Trophy? A Risky Decision Due to Limited Pace Options A Smart Move to Adapt to Dubai’s Conditions

Go Beyond The Boundary with our YouTube channel.

'We don't look at averages and stats': Gautam Gambhir on sending Axar Patel at No. 5

NEW DELHI: Eyebrows were raised when India announced five spinners in the team for the ICC Champions Trophy . Historically, the pitches in Dubai do not overly favour spinners. However, the venue has also just got done with the month-long ILT20 league which may have left the pitches tired and more amenable to spin. Predominantly, though, India’s spinner-heavy squad was chosen to lengthen the batting lineup, TOI has learnt.The trend emerging from head coach Gautam Gambhir ’s tenure is the inclination to have more allrounders in the lineup across formats. Gambhir has been vocal about the need to bat deep. Seambowling allrounders are a rarity at the moment. Hence, Washington Sundar too has made the cut along with Axar Patel and Ravindra Jadeja Interestingly, it was Gambhir who insisted on having Shivam Dube back in the ODI scheme of things by adding him to the list of non-travelling reserves, say insiders.Gambhir is someone who prefers to have more options in the playing XI. More allrounders give him the chance to be flexible. If India advance in the tournament, spinners are likely to play a greater role.The idea, according to those in the know of developments, is simple — play two steady finger-spinners who can bat well to complement either Kuldeep Yadav or Varun Chakravarthy . Kuldeep and Chakravarthy are seen as genuine strike options. If the pitches at the start look like they can produce big runs, one might see Chakravarthy in the XI ahead of Kuldeep. The majority of Chakravarthy’s wickets have come while the batters have been looking to push the scoring rate. Kuldeep is seen as someone who can deceive the batter in the air and lure him into a false shot, like he did against England in the last ODI in Ahmedabad on Wednesday.Also See: Champions Trophy Schedule 2025 There are other factors too. India have played two Asia Cups at the venue over the last seven years and never played more than two frontline spinners in the XI.Jasprit Bumrah’s absence and Mohammed Shami being rusty after a long injury layoff has played a part in India picking a spin-heavy attack which can compensate for the inexperience of the two new pacers, Harshit Rana and Arshdeep Singh. It will be interesting to see how India’s campaign unfolds on the Dubai pitches, which usually sport a layering of grass to prevent the surface from cracking up.
Article Summary: The trend emerging from head coach Gautam Gambhir ’s tenure is the inclination to have more allrounders in the lineup across formats. The idea, according to those in the know of developments, is simple — play two steady finger-spinners who can bat well to complement Kuldeep Yadav or Varun Chakravarthy.

Kevin Kiermaier talks about new role with Blue Jays | Hot Stove

Kevin Kiermaier, the four-time Gold Glove-winning outfielder, has hung up his cleats for a clipboard to join the Toronto Blue Jays coaching staff as a special assistant and outfield guru. It appears the man that wowed fans with his impossible catches and laser-accurate throws is now imparting that magic to the next generation of outfielders.Kevin Kiermaier, freshly retired after a season under the Jays, took a moment to explain why he is looking toward coaching: Outfield is his thing and he wants to teach it. On MLB Network, he was adamant: He wants to impart the knowledge he has garnered over years of chasing fly balls and saving runs so that the next group of players can achieve their potential.Kiermaier, with that smile that could make any Blue Jays fan's heart skip a beat, said: "Outfield is my thing, and I just wanna teach it to the next group of players coming up." Although he never wowed anyone with his offensive numbers (career-low .246 hitter, for the stat geeks), Kiermaier was in a whole different ball park altogether with his defense.Consistency was really what defined him; making jaw-dropping plays look routine won him Gold Gloves along the way, including one for his efforts with the Blue Jays in 2023. Grace and precision in roaming the outfield are what make him the perfect fit for the role. After all, whom better than the guy who could almost predict the path of a baseball with the same accuracy as a magician reading through a crystal ball to teach the finer points of reading a fly ball?Kiermaier's coaching position will surely benefit Toronto's outfield players. Having been on the biggest stage assisting the Rays to the World Series in 2020, he brings not only technical skills, but the wisdom that comes from playoff-level pressure.The Jays find themselves with bona fide outfield expertise on the staff, some fueled with enough fire for it to turn their next crop of outfielders into Gold Glove contenders. While switching from player to coach might be a substantial transition, for Kevin Kiermaier, it is just one more opportunity to fly high.
Article Summary: Kevin Kiermaier, the four-time Gold Glove-winning outfielder, has hung up his cleats for a clipboard to join the Toronto Blue Jays coaching staff. He wants to impart the knowledge he has garnered over years of chasing fly balls and saving runs to the next group of players.

Article Title: "More to grab on": Ciara shares how Russell Wilson is more obsessed than ever with her body after baby no. 4

Ciara Says Russell Wilson Adores Her Body Even More After Welcoming Their Fourth Child



Motherhood has always been a transformative journey for Ciara , and with the birth of her fourth child, Amora, in December 2023, the singer found herself in yet another phase of self-discovery. Despite being no stranger to bouncing back after pregnancy, the 39-year-old entertainer admitted that this time, her body responded differently. However, rather than being overly critical, she is choosing to embrace the changes, especially with the unwavering support of her husband, NFL star Russell Wilson .In an interview with Bustle for The Little Things issue, Ciara opened up about the rapid transition she underwent as she prepared to return to the stage just months after giving birth. Joining Missy Elliott on tour so soon after welcoming her daughter was a challenge she described as feeling “a little out-of-body.” Although this wasn’t her first time navigating the demands of performing post-pregnancy, she acknowledged that age has introduced new factors into her recovery process. “It's not the first time I've had to do this. I've been there before, but your body changes as you get older. I'm trying to embrace every step," she shared.Unlike previous experiences, where she would have been tough on herself for not regaining her pre-baby physique quickly, Ciara is now approaching the journey with a renewed perspective.“I would've probably been so hard on myself because I hadn't made it back to where I was, post-baby,” she reflected. Instead of self-criticism, she has found appreciation for this version of herself, lovingly acknowledging the subtle changes brought about by her latest pregnancy. “I also was kind of loving this fourth-baby version of me,” she said. With Wilson by her side, her confidence has only grown, as he reassures her that the changes are something to be embraced. "My baby definitely put a little bit more on my hips and there is, as Russell says, 'more to grab on.’”Even as she focuses on getting stronger, Ciara revealed that Wilson keeps her in check when she contemplates an intense fitness regimen. “I want to lean up a little bit more, tone up more, and he's like, 'Don't get crazy,'” she joked, highlighting how her husband encourages her to love herself in every stage of life.Beyond fitness and body positivity, family planning is another topic that frequently comes up for the couple. During a recent interview, when Jenna Bush Hager asked about the possibility of baby number five, Ciara coyly responded, “I do. I do!” While she expressed excitement about expanding their family, she also hinted at needing some time before another addition. “My youngest is one, so listen, there’s a trend with all of our babies –– they’re all three years apart.” Though she clarified that following this pattern wasn’t a strict requirement, she made it clear that she wasn't in a rush.However, Wilson seems more than ready for another baby. “If it’s up to Russ, ‘cinco’ is coming next month, but we got a little time, baby,” she quipped, playfully referring to their potential fifth child as “baby cinco.”Also Read: "I never lost hope, I never lost faith": Feeling ‘Disrespected’ by Giants, Saquon Barkley turned doubt into dominance this season She also shared that it’s all about the effort to keep the “spark” and attraction alive. “You need to still turn up the sexy," Ciara, 39, told the outlet. "He walks through the door, and I’m like, ‘OK!’ Because he intentionally went in to go get sexier, to get cute. For me, the same thing."With a home filled with love, laughter, and support, Ciara continues to thrive in both her personal and professional life. And with Wilson as her biggest cheerleader, she proves that embracing change can be a beautiful thing.

Article Title: "I bleed for this city": Philadelphia Eagles GM Howie Roseman gets cut after beer can hits him at Super Bowl victory parade
Article Text:
Credit: AP Photos

Howie Roseman Takes a Hit but Leads Eagles' Super Bowl Parade with Pride



Philadelphia Eagles fans are known for their unrelenting passion, and they proved it once again as they flooded the streets of the city to celebrate their team’s dominant Super Bowl LIX victory. The championship parade, an event filled with energy and jubilation, took an unexpected turn when Eagles general manager Howie Roseman was struck by a flying beer can, leaving him with a visible wound on his forehead. Despite the minor injury, Roseman remained unfazed, continuing to march alongside team owner Jeffrey Lurie in front of a roaring crowd.As images of Roseman’s injury circulated on social media, fans were both amused and concerned about the incident. NBC Sports Philadelphia confirmed that the can hit Roseman, causing a small gash, but the resilient executive took it in stride. Eagles pass rusher Josh Sweat, who was instrumental in the defensive effort that shut down Patrick Mahomes, couldn’t help but laugh at the mishap.“I laughed at him a little bit when it happened,” Sweat admitted. “And I know he's mad at me. ... When I saw it, I knew what happened, and I couldn't contain my laugh. ... I did not throw the can at him. But hey, that’s part of it! They’re throwing full cans and bottles.”The incident, however, did not deter Roseman from celebrating in style. With a cut on his forehead and a cigar in hand, the veteran executive continued his triumphant march through the streets of Philadelphia, proving that nothing— not even a flying beer can—could dampen his championship spirit.Roseman’s journey with the Eagles has been nothing short of remarkable. Having started with the organization in 2000 as a front office intern, he worked his way up to become general manager and executive vice president. Over the past eight seasons, he has built two Super Bowl-winning teams, cementing his reputation as one of the NFL’s most astute executives.As the mastermind behind a franchise that has appeared in three Super Bowls and won two in just eight years, Roseman addressed the sea of Eagles fans gathered in front of the Philadelphia Museum of Art with a fiery proclamation.“I bleed for this city! Go Eagles!” he declared, still sporting the fresh wound. “Our players, our staff did an unbelievable job. We are two-time world champs, and we’re coming back strong!”His leadership was on full display this season, especially in the way he reconstructed a struggling defense. After the Eagles finished 26th in total defense and 30th in scoring defense in 2023, Roseman took bold action, selecting standout cornerbacks Quinyon Mitchell and Cooper DeJean in the draft while securing linebacker Zack Baun in free agency. The revamped defense was a major factor in Philadelphia’s 40-22 dismantling of the Kansas City Chiefs in Super Bowl LIX, where Mahomes was sacked six times and intercepted twice, preventing the Chiefs from making NFL history with a three-peat.As the confetti settles, Roseman’s work is far from over. The Eagles face a crucial offseason, with key players such as Baun, Josh Sweat, Milton Williams, and Mekhi Becton set to hit free agency. However, with Roseman at the helm, the franchise remains well-positioned to compete at the highest level for years to come.Also Read: Eagles fans belt out ‘We Are the Champions’ as Philadelphia goes green on Valentine’s Day to celebrate Super Bowl victory While the beer can incident added an unexpected twist to the celebrations, it also served as a fitting symbol of Roseman’s relentless dedication to Philadelphia. He may have left the parade with a scar, but it’s a mark of the battles he’s fought—and won—for this city. As Eagles fans continue to bask in the glory of another championship, one thing is certain: their team, led by Roseman, is far from finished.
Article Summary: Eagles general manager Howie Roseman was struck by a flying beer can during the team's Super Bowl LIX parade. Roseman remained unfazed, continuing to march alongside team owner Jeffrey Lurie in front of a roaring crowd. Eagles pass rusher Josh Sweat, who was instrumental in the defensive effort that shut down Patrick Mahomes, couldn't help but laugh at the mishap.

Article Title: 2nd ODI: Virat Kohli's in, but who's out? Selection dilemma as India look to seal series against England
Article Text:
Virat Kohli during a practice session. (PTI Photo)

Go Beyond The Boundary with our YouTube channel.

'It’s a slightly two-paced pitch': Harshit Rana after claiming three-wicket haul on ODI debut

CUTTACK: One look at the stands on Saturday evening at the Barabati Stadium , and one could have been forgiven for mistaking it for match day instead of match eve.The Odisha Cricket Association 's (OCA) decision to open part of the stands for fans to watch India train, for free, ahead of the crucial second ODI against England here was a hit, with the stadium nearly half full.The loudest cheers from the 20,000-plus crowd were reserved for the man who missed the first ODI in Nagpur with a sore right knee — Virat Kohli Saturday's nets, however, suggested Kohli was not going to sit out another game. One of the fittest cricketers around, the former India captain last missed a match — before the Nagpur ODI — more than three years ago, the Johannesburg Test against South Africa in Jan 2022. Fit and raring to go, the star batter was the first to hit the nets and batted for nearly an hour before leaving the ground first, shouldering his cricket coffin.While England completely skipped Saturday's practice, many India players also skipped the optional session, including last-match hero Shreyas Iyer , vice-captain Shubman Gill , debutant Harshit Rana, comeback man Mohammed Shami, Hardik Pandya and Axar Patel."Virat Kohli is fit to play. He has come for practice and is good to go," batting coach Sitanshu Kotak said during the prematch media interaction.With a fit-again Kohli back in the playing XI, India will face a selection dilemma as they prepare to tick all the boxes ahead of the Champions Trophy and seal the series before going to Ahmedabad.Will Iyer lose his place to Kohli if the team management decides to continue with Yashasvi Jaiswal to keep the left-right opening combination going with captain Rohit Sharma ? Kotak, however, bypassed any queries on who should make way for Kohli on Sunday."I think that's what the head coach and captain can talk about. But yes, definitely a lefty-righty combination is there. But I would say that question is not something which I would like to answer, to be very honest," was Kotak's diplomatic answer.Rohit's form will certainly also be a concern for the side, no matter how the management tries to brush aside any doubts regarding his continuous run of poor form. Rohit, incidentally, got out after scoring only two runs in the first ODI of this series.Rohit coming back into form will certainly be a big boost for the hosts ahead of the ICC event starting on Feb 19. The track looks a belter and could well be the right platform for the ‘Hitman' to get some much-needed runs under his belt.Meanwhile, KL Rahul is likely to get another look-in as the wicketkeeper-batter ahead of Rishabh Pant, who batted for long in the nets. However, left-arm pacer Arshdeep Singh bowled long spells during the practice session and could replace Shami, who might be rested to manage his workload following a long injury layoff.Although dew factor is unlikely to come into play here, batting second will be the preferred choice, as chasing teams have won 12 out of the 19 ODIs played here over the years.
Article Summary: Virat Kohli was the first to hit the nets and batted for nearly an hour before leaving the ground first, shouldering his cricket coffin. The loudest cheers from the 20,000-plus crowd were reserved for the man who missed the first ODI in Nagpur with a sore right knee. England completely skipped Saturday's practice, but many India players also skipped the optional session.

Article Title: Kevin Pietersen : 'Do me a f*****g favour! Stop writing about cricket ...' Pietersen slams UK journalist over England's training controversy

Former England cricketer Kevin Pietersen has taken aim at a 'leading' UK journalist for defending England's lack of practice during their tour of India. Pietersen, who has been vocal about England’s struggles, lashed out on social media after the journalist cited injuries and a tight schedule as reasons for the team's training omissions."Just got sent an article where a leading UK journo has said that Shastri & I got it wrong last night when discussing England not training. Reason - injuries and quick turnaround between games…!" Pietersen posted on X."Do me a f*****g favour! Stop writing about cricket if you’re going to write such rubbish. Injuries are part of sport and this schedule is like every bilateral series almost ever played. Injuries are NOT stopping batters from batting against net bowlers and learning the art of playing spin. And that’s where they should have been to IMPROVE! Trust me on this one as it saved my career against spin!" Pietersen wrote.He further suggested that the journalist was trying to mislead fans, writing, "It seems the journos are in cahoots with what we’re trying to be brainwashed into believing! You won’t fool the fan with such!"Also See: 2025 Champions Trophy Pietersen had already expressed his frustration over England’s lack of preparation in India, calling it "gobsmacking" that the team did not hold a single practice session after losing the first ODI and the T20I series.England endured a disastrous tour, losing the T20I series 4-1 before being swept 3-0 in the ODIs. Reports suggested that England avoided net sessions due to mounting injuries and a demanding schedule, but Pietersen dismissed these justifications, emphasising the importance of preparation, particularly in the subcontinent."There isn't a single sportsman on this planet who can honestly say they’d improve without practicing whilst they’re getting beaten," he posted. "There also cannot be one player in that England side that can sit on the plane leaving India and say to themselves, they did everything they could to help England win. And for that, I’m actually incredibly sad this evening. Losing is fine if you're giving your best to improve every day, and if England didn't train during this series then they didn’t try."During commentary for the third ODI, Pietersen highlighted how England’s approach was reflected in their activities off the field. He noted that Tom Banton , who replaced the injured Jacob Bethell, was seen playing golf a day before the match instead of practicing."I never played golf when I played cricket. I was in the nets hitting thousands of balls, trying to make improvements here in the sub-continent. Have your days off in England."England captain Jos Buttler, however, defended the team’s preparation, stating, "I'm not sure that's quite true, to be honest. We had a reasonably long tour, a few long travel days. There's been a couple of times we've not trained, but we've certainly done plenty of training throughout the tour.""We obviously try and create a really good environment, but don’t mistake that for a lazy environment or a lack of effort. The guys are desperate to perform and do well and improve," Buttler added.Former India coach Ravi Shastri , who was also critical of England’s lack of training, remarked, "From what I’ve heard, England have had just one net session this entire trip, if not any. If you're not prepared to do the hard yards, you're not going to improve."With England’s struggles against spin exposed throughout the tour, concerns are mounting ahead of the upcoming ICC Champions Trophy in Pakistan and the UAE. Pietersen’s blunt assessment has ignited a fresh debate about England’s preparation and mindset on overseas tours.
Article Summary: Former England cricketer Kevin Pietersen has taken aim at a 'leading' UK journalist for defending England's lack of practice during their tour of India. Pietersen lashed out on social media after the journalist cited injuries and a tight schedule as reasons for the team's training omissions.
